title: The NCAA’s Student-Athlete Fiction
sub_head: They are admitted to play sports. Pay them to do so and dispense with all the fake majors.
body:
I applaud Prof. Thomas Miller Jr.’s attempt, in extending scholarships, to reconcile the obvious incompatibility of a traditional four-year academic education in a rigorous discipline with the fiction of the student-athlete (“Student-Athletes Deserve 10-Year Scholarships,” op-ed, July 29).
The current system, including the redshirt year, does not permit the student-athlete to pursue a degree in a rigorous subject. Consequently, less-than-rigorous majors such as parks administration developed for student-athletes. I recall during the 1950s, when the profiles of the players and their majors were announced at halftime during bowl games, it was common to hear pre-med, pre-law, economics, history, etc. Rarely, if ever, do I hear those academic pursuits cited today, if players’ academic profiles are cited at all.
Student-athletes now can expect to meet relaxed admissions standards. This is true for many colleges, save perhaps the Ivies and the military academies—which is why their Division I teams are so bad. Effectively, student-athletes are gaining “admission” to pursue their sports. Why not simply hire them for their athletic talents and pay them salaries for those four or five years of playing time?
Would this not be far more honest than attempting to put a round peg in a square hole?
Alan R. Lichtenstein
